results.title: Better than any sport
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Boss Class”.
This film shows how up-to-date British managers achieve their objectives. Typical management problems are explained by case histories - exporting and takeovers by the Leyland Group (Sir Donald Stokes), Marks and Spencer’s philosophy of marketing, and then a small manufacturer (Jim Houston) talks of his experience with a new highly technological product.

group_siblings.title: People are the main part of any deal

results.title: People are the main part of any deal
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Boss Class”.
In part Two the problems of management are further discussed with particular reference to industrial relations, training and consultation of staff and fringe benefits. Summarises three problems facing industry - innovation, computerisation and containerisation.

group_works.title: The Facts for girls
group_works.creator_credit: Alfred Kelman, Robert E. Fuisz and Time-Life Films

results.title: The Facts for girls
results.creator_credit: Alfred Kelman, Robert E. Fuisz and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Body Human”.
Illustrations of the female biological functions are interspersed with informal, live-action discussions at an all-girls’ slumber party, on a jogging track and during other typical teenage activities. Besides the female anatomy, they discuss menstruation, reproduction and the girls’ hopes and fears. Narrated by Marlo Thomas and photographed by Don Lenzer.

results.title: Ice society
results.creator_credit: Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Big ice: views of Antarctica”.
This series examines the great southern continent and man’s connection with it. This particular film, which is episode four, looks at the intriguing adaptations, both physical and behavioural, of plant and wildlife in the inhospitable surroundings of the Antarctic.

results.title: Out of sight, out of mind
results.creator_credit: Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Big ice: views of Antarctica”.
Looks at the history of Antarctic exploration, incorporating still photographs and rare archival film. Includes footage of the expeditions of Scott, Amundsen and Shackleton and Admiral Byrd’s flight to the South Pole, with Sir Edmund Hillary’s tractor journey to the pole.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit

results.title: The Water of life
results.creator_credit: Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Big ice: views of Antarctica”.
The Antarctic continent is a unique natural laboratory for the study of simple life forms, and of physical and behavioural adaptations to inhospitable surroundings. The ocean surrounding Antarctica also has the world’s greatest untrapped food supply. The film asks whether controlled exploitation and development can take place without upsetting the delicate balance of nature.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit

results.title: Blowing hot and cold
results.creator_credit: Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Big ice: views of Antarctica”.
Provides statistics on some aspects of the Antarctic continent such as the size of the landmass as compared to Australia and the types of weather conditions experienced. Also presents the latest scientific evidence on the effect of the Antarctic ice mass on world climate. Suitable for secondary and tertiary levels.
